The dancing bear is one of the most well-known subjects in Inuit art ‚îÄ and the most challenging to carve. The Canol Trail is known as one of the world‚Äôs most challenging trails. It runs through the Mackenzie Mountains west of Norman Wells, Northwest Territories. The rough terrain includes risks to humans like grizzly bears and fast-moving water. The trail is also a designated contaminated site, due to elements leftover from an old pipeline constructed during the Second World War. Recently, a contract was awarded to Englobe Corp. (NWT) to clean up the trail. Remediation of the trail will reduce risks to people, animals and the environment associated with the abandoned pipeline and related infrastructure. This remediation project will benefit the local economy and provide job opportunities to the Sahtu communities. To learn more about the Canol Trail Remediation Project, visit:

Congratulations to partners involved in the development of the Nunavut Wellness Agreement. Through this agreement, the Government of Canada will provide funding to the Government of Nunavut for community-based programs covering four broad areas: healthy children, families and communities; healthy living; mental wellness; and home and community care. Learn more about the Nunavut Wellness Agreement:

Happy National Aboriginal Day to all people living in the North!

Biology students from √âcole St. Patrick High School in Yellowknife, NWT, learned about environmental monitoring from biologists working on the Giant Mine Remediation Project. Students received hands-on eerience with the Giant Mine Remediation Project team on how environmental monitoring helps ensure the safety, health and protection of Northerners and the environment. While students took samples of invertebrates (small bugs), water, sediment, and small fish for live release from the Yellowknife River, project team members elained how the different types of sampling help evaluate the health of an ecosystem. The Project team was excited to show students a real-life application of the science they are learning in the classroom.

Did you know that % of Inuit living in Nunavut speak Inuktitut as their mother tongue? Inuit languages in Nunavut can be written using roman orthography (the alphabet used in English) or using syllabics (an alphabet used for a number of Indigenous languages in Canada). Learn more about the language here: 1 "

It's National Seal Products Day! A Bill creating this national day was adopted by the House of Commons of the Government of Canada on May , . In Canada's North, seal harvesters, processors, artisans and Inuit produce some of the finest quality seal products in the world and contribute to Canada‚Äôs economy. Learn about this sustainable economic activity and its social and cultural importance:

Muskoxen (named "omingmak" by the Inuit) are large, shaggy relatives of mountain sheep and mountain goats. Their thick layer of insulating underwool, called "qiviut" lets them brave the northern winter's fiercest conditions. In fact, qiviut is times warmer than cashmere! Learn about muskox survival strategies, diet, and more: 8

Did you know that Canada's North is home to about species of flowering plants? Despite long, harsh winters, there are brief but colourful summers. Purple saxifrage is an example of a flower that can be admired even in Parks Canada's northernmost National Park, Quttinirpaaq. Learn more about this northern jewel, which is also Nunavut's official flower!
